profileDesc.abstract: A letter from T. H. at Kilburn to Mary, describing recent excursions in London, including the Thames Tunnel and the Monument, and plans for returning home.

bibl.title: Letter from T. H. to Mary
bibl.creator: T. H.

body.p: I suppose you are very glad that Xmas is coming. Do not send back the Sat. No's but take care of them and put them in your box, so that I may have them when I want them— I wish you wd tell me how u. r. when u. write. I have a c—— “cold & it is by head” so I have stayed in all day to be all right to morrow.

Last Friday night there was a conversazione (pronounced Ron-ver-sat-zi-on-e) at the Architectural Association's rooms. There were about 300, or 400 present, including your humble servant. Mr Blomfield, one of the Committee, gave me a ticket, and Mr Bunker, another Committee man, another, &c. I gave to Shaw and we went together. After lots of speechifying from learned professors, there was music &c, and coffee—this last rather in small quantities. Many ladies were there; and of course in full dress. Shaw lent me a dress coat (thus ☞ as I did not possess one). My name was proposed amongst many others, for becoming a member…

only means paying 10/– a year. Miss A. and Father went off all right, as you know. Do you ever write to Eliza? Father enjoyed himself, strangely. I took them to hear the Opera of Lurlina at Covent Garden, but nothing would satisfy Father unless he went to see the Thames Tunnel. This, you know, is 5 or 6 miles from Kilburn, and lies in one of the lowest and most crowded parts of London.

Accordingly, one morning he started off alone, agreeing to meet Miss A. at the foot of the Monument on Tower Hill at 1 o’clock. She had been somewhere not mentioned during the morning. What is to be wondered at is the fact that they actually did meet; but as Father was there a little too soon, he went to the top of the Monument (200 feet). ——— —— —— —— —— —— —— Well, they went to the T. T. together and came home all right.

I expect to come home Xmas for a little time. Frank Lock is living in London & is coming to see me. Perhaps Shaw may come down with me for a day or two Xmas. It will be good fun, he is such a “coddle” & I paying the outing. ——— —— —— ——

closer.p: I am very economical of paper as u. may see.
closer.signed: Goodbye. Henry wrote yesterday. T. H.
